@snacklesbian Back at you! ‚ù§Ô∏è We deeply appreciate being in solidarity with patients like you. We're all in these fights together, and together is the only way we can win them.

@snacklesbian To be fair, that‚Äôs what WE call these programs. Hospitals call them ‚Äúenhanced‚Äù education, training, or new nurse orientation programs, graduate apprenticeships, immigrant nurse sponsorships. We know what they really are, though: Schemes to make new nurses shoulder training costs!
You can help us better understand the impact of employer-driven debt on health care workers' professional and personal choices and lives by taking our survey! (9/9) https://t.co/NHTZeOiBQM

But union nurses are committed to fighting back! ‚úä 

Have you experienced a program like the kind we've described here? Do you know or work with someone who has?

We want to hear about it!üëÇ (8/9)

These contracts discourage union membership and intimidate employees into silence ‚Äî forcing them to choose between financial ruin or speaking out against unsafe working conditions and unsafe patient care.

All of this because they know: Our collective voice is powerful! (7/9)

These predatory practices trap workers AND place an unfair burden on new hires to fund their own on-the-job training! üò°

These exploitative practices are becoming more and more common, deepening existing power imbalances between workers and management. (6/9) https://t.co/avJGZYqMit

You may even be forced to pay back work-related expenses like necessary training, application and recruitment fees, and relocation costs.

Your employer may even withhold your final paychecks or harass you with bills after you've left! (5/9)

These contracts require workers to stay employed at the hospital for a set period of time and lock them into low wages ‚Äî significantly less than union workers.

And if you resign or you are terminated before that time period ends?

You guessed it: You incur a penalty! üí∏ (4/9)

In reality, these employer-mandated programs simply pass on the costs of basic on-the-job training to health care workers. 

(Yes, these are the same people crying crocodile tears over a so-called "nursing shortage" of their own creation.) (3/9)

Buried in the fine print of long contracts, hospitals slip in huge fees for so-called tuition, coursework, and other costs. 

Often mandatory, hospitals tout these programs as graduate apprenticeships, immigrant nurse sponsorships, or ‚Äúenhanced‚Äù trainings. (2/9)

‚úÖ Recognizes aerosol transmission of Covid,

(10/10)

FACT: A vast body of research shows that even asymptomatic and mild infections can result in long Covid consequences like new onset diabetes and cognitive decline. 

(9/10)

FACT: Repeated surges in Covid-19 infections, hospitalizations, and deaths put nurses and other health care workers at heightened and perpetual risk from infection and #MoralInjury. 

(8/10)

FACT: The pandemic is not over, and neither is virus evolution.

We cannot predict how this virus will evolve, but failure to prevent widespread transmission will result in further evolution and spread of variants that may be more severe and evade vaccine protection.

(7/10)

FACT: Both legally and morally, health care employers have an obligation to invest in and prioritize the health and safety of their employees. 

Hospitals should be centers of healing, not a source of infection, because when nurses are safe, patients are safe. 

(6/10)

FACT: Weak guidelines from @CDCgov are not based on science and endanger workers, patients, and public health.

These weak guidelines encourage employers to cut costs and boost profits instead of planning for patient and public health needs. 

(5/10)

(4/10)

In 1967, Tiger was elected as the first female chief of the Seminole tribe ‚Äî and is believed to be the first woman elected to such leadership of any federally recognized tribe.

Thank you Betty Mae for forging a vision and blazing a path for future generations! (6/6) https://t.co/EEvphIxWsz
She returned to Florida & brought modern medicine to her people. She helped create the tribe‚Äôs Indian Health Program and became its first health director. (5/6) https://t.co/mMKvjSyL9Y

She persuaded her mother to let her leave home for a Cherokee boarding school in North Carolina. 

In 1949, she became the first recognized Seminole to graduate from high school and later nursing school ‚Äì also a first! (4/6) https://t.co/B3d8KmXvCp

To protect Tiger, the family moved to the Dania federal reservation. 

In Florida‚Äôs segregated school system, she was not allowed to attend white schools because she was Indigenous, and not allowed to attend Black schools because she was perceived as too white. (3/6)

She was born in 1923 to a Seminole midwife of the Snake clan and a French trapper, and narrowly survived childhood. To protect its clan from genocide and forced-relocation, tribal leaders outlawed ‚Äòmiscegenation‚Äô between Seminole and white people. (2/6) https://t.co/K6eZ94ELOR

National Nurses United salutes and celebrates Jessie Sleet Scales' incalculable contributions to nursing practice, #PublicHealth, racial justice, and #BlackHistory! üôåüèæ

(10/10) https://t.co/g4h1Y8An1g

Scales went on to work with other pioneering nurses who advocated that #HealthCareIsAHumanRight including Elizabeth Tyler, Edith Carter, and Lillian Wald.

Together, they founded a settlement house in San Juan Hill ‚Äî a Black community near present-day Columbus Circle.

(9/10) https://t.co/NJevwhw0Fk

She exceeded her employers' expectations, and her first report was published in the American Journal of Nursing in 1901. #BlackHistoryMonth 

(8/10)

She was directed to treat Black tuberculosis patients in their homes. Tuberculosis hit Black communities especially hard due to economic and social conditions created by #SystemicRacism.

(7/10)

In 1900, she was at last hired, on a two-month conditional basis, becoming the first Black district nurse for The Charity Organization Society.

(6/10)

There was a strong demand for district nurses in New York, and Scales was eminently qualified ‚Äî yet she was denied many positions on the basis of being Black. #BlackHistoryMatters

(5/10)

Scales completed additional courses at Freedmen's Hospital ‚Äî now Howard University Hospital ‚Äî which was founded as the first hospital of its kind to aid in the medical treatment of former slaves.

She aspired to become a district nurse.üí™üèøüí™üèæüí™üèΩ (4/10) https://t.co/oeuL83zXJ6

In 1895, Scales graduated from the Provident Training School for Nursing in Chicago ‚Äî the first Black-owned, integrated hospital in the U.S.

(Emma Reynolds, another pioneering Black nurse, helped found Provident when she was denied entry into other training programs!) (3/10) https://t.co/VQiU6hSXR7
Scales was born in 1865 in Ontario, Canada üá®üá¶ ‚Äî the ‚Äúlast station‚Äù on the Underground Railroad ‚Äî where thousands of Black refugees settled after escaping slavery in the U.S. (2/10)

In 1900, Reynolds joined the faculty of Freedmen's Hospital ‚Äî now known as Howard University Hospital.

The hospital was funded with donations from prominent leaders like Frederick Douglass, as well as from Black working-class residents of South Side, Chicago.

Emma Reynolds was in the first graduating class of nurses. üéì  (6/10)

Thanks to grassroots people power, the #MedicareForAll Act of 2021 (#HR1976) was introduced in Congress with a record 112 original cosponsors.

Here's what it will take to secure our collective path to ‚úåÔ∏èvictory‚úåÔ∏è...

Nurses know ‚Äî without a doubt ‚Äî that if we‚Äôd had a #MedicareForAll system in the U.S. that guarantees health care to all free at the point of service, the pandemic would have played out a lot differently for millions of families.

Our fight is more urgent than ever.

Covid exposed deep systemic #racism that has existed for centuries in health care.

Black, Latinx, and Indigenous people are 3x as likely to contract #Covid19 and 2x as likely to die from it, in part due to a lower likelihood to have health insurance or receive preventative care.

The current system is devastating for our patients too.

We saw an estimated 27 million people in the U.S. kicked off employer-sponsored health insurance last year.

This is in addition to the 29M people who had no insurance AND the 41M who were #underinsured before the pandemic.

#Nurses can‚Äôt get the PPE needed to keep ourselves and our patients safe because hospitals refuse to keep enough on hand ‚Äî all in the name of keeping costs ‚¨áÔ∏è and profits ‚¨ÜÔ∏è.

As a result, nearly 400 RNs have died from #Covid19 ‚Äî deaths due largely to corporate greed. https://t.co/jGBy1dL8D8

For nurses, the fight to win #MedicareForAll has become deeply personal.

Union RNs have long fought for single-payer health care on behalf of our patients, but in the pandemic it's become painfully clear that for many hospital corporations, #nurses are expendable.

But repression from the 1% couldn't stamp out workers' fire for justice.

Labor rebels, including #LucyParsons, a fierce working-class organizer & widow of #HaymarketMartyr Albert Parsons, rallied people across the U.S. & around the world to keep rising up each #MayDay.

8Ô∏è‚É£ labor leaders were‚Äî without evidence‚Äî tried for the #HaymarketRiot. 4Ô∏è‚É£ were convicted & executed. 

State repression didn't end there.

11/13

To protest the murders at the hands of police, #labor leaders called a mass meeting in #Haymarket Square for May 4.

10/13 https://t.co/4bBJkDzXAJ

#MayDay was a smashing success across the U.S., and many struck for multiple days.
 
Chicago was the epicenter, where McCormick company ironworkers led the way. In retribution, company-sponsored police shot & killed four of them.
 
(#PoliceViolence IS a labor issue.)

9/13

1884 ‚û°Ô∏è The Federation of Organized Trades & Labour Unions ‚Äî a forerunner of the @AFLCIO ‚Äî holds a convention where workers resolve to take militant collective action for the 8-hour day.
 
They choose #MayDay, 1886 for the strike and organize like hell for 2 years.üì∞üì¢üó£Ô∏è

8/13

1835: Irish coal workers in Philly organized a general strike. Their banners read: From 6 to 6, ten hours work and two hours for meals.
 
Workers' publications called for an 8-hour day as early as 1836.
 
As folks kept organizing, workers started to WIN their demands.üì¢üí™üéâ

7/13 https://t.co/IeAHzI55SI

An international sense of #solidarity was in the air, inspired in part by the French Revolution where workers toppled monarchy rule, won expanded suffrage and a shorter work day.

U.S. workers decided it was their turn to win a battle in the #ClassWar.

6/13 https://t.co/hOpY36chtX

Drawing on the long-history of communal resistance associated with #MayDay, workers chose May 1st for this massive protest.
 
Here's what went down:

üí•As early as 1791, carpenters in Philly struck for a shorter day.

Similar actions spread across the country like wildfire.

5/13

Fast forward to #May1st, 1886.
 
Half a million workers across the U.S. ‚Äî who had been subjected to 100+ hour work weeks ‚Äî walked off the job, united in their demand for an 8-hour work day with NO cut in pay.
 
üì¢ Half. A. Million.üî•
 
Bosses were shook.üé©üò±

4/13

#MayDay was a time workers put away their tools & gathered flowers, danced, feasted, held ceremony, built fires, shared libations, and celebrated community.üåªüíÉüî•
 
Because workers weren't grinding away making profits for a boss, many May Day celebrations were criminalized.

3/13 https://t.co/08vMTGq3Jp

Scientific research underlines the major aspects of this standard.
 
Employers must:
‚úÖ Engage nurses' active participation in developing the plan
‚úÖ Provide staffing and procedures for a prompt response
‚úÖ Provide hands-on training
‚úÖ Create unit-specific plans
 
8/_

This bill will improve nurse safety, and patient safety alike, by preventing violence in the workplace BEFORE it happens.
 
Criminalizing or blaming patients is NOT part of this bill.
 
7/_

The bill places responsibility where it belongs‚Äî WITH EMPLOYERS‚Äî to provide a safe workplace for nurses and other health care workers.
 
It focuses on what employers can and should do to PREVENT workplace violence before it happens.
 
6/_

Coverage is expansive.
 
The bill:
üá∫üá∏ Applies to all 50 states
üè• Covers a wide range of health care and social service workplaces
‚öîÔ∏è Has a broad definition of workplace violence that covers not just physical violence but threats and incidents involving weapons
 
5/_

.@RepJoeCourtney's bill would mandate that @OSHA_DOL‚Äî the Occupational Safety and Health Administration ‚Äî create a standard requiring health care and social service employers to implement comprehensive workplace violence prevention plans.
 
4/_

For nurses, this trend has only gotten worse during the pandemic.
 
In November, 2020, NNU surveyed more than 15,000 RNs across the U.S. & found that about 20 percent of nurses reported facing INCREASED #WorkplaceViolence on the job since the start of the #Covid19 pandemic.
 
3/_

Employer failure to #ProtectNurses has existed for decades.
 
According to @BLS_gov's 2019 data, health care and social service workers reported FIVE TIMES the rate of injury due to #WorkplaceViolence than workers overall.
 
2/_

#WorkplaceViolence is on the rise in health care settings across the country, compounded by the #Covid19 crisis.

It's past time Claudette Colvin was recognized alongside the many other great Civil Rights activists publicly praised for their contributions to the ongoing struggle for Black liberation.

Claudette, #UnionStrong nurses honor you!

9/9 https://t.co/jFOIobnRnm

Despite her contributions to the movement, Claudette did not receive the support she deserved.

As a result of ongoing racist retaliation for her role in the desegregation of Alabama's buses, she was forced out of state and finally found work in New York as a nurses' aide.

8/9

Her case made it to the Supreme Court, where the growing people power of the Civil Rights movement made it impossible for the justices to do anything but agree with Colvin.

Her case was a massive win for the Montgomery bus boycott, and all those fighting for justice.

7/9 https://t.co/K5OZjXGRoH

Claudette was labeled a young Black "troublemaker," which brought debilitating consequences: She was denied work, fired from multiple jobs, and forced to drop out of school.

Still, Claudette became a plaintiff in Browder v. Gayle, challenging Alabama's bus segregation.

6/9

To cope, while held at an adult jail awaiting bail, young Claudette focused her mind on all she was learning.

"I recited Edgar Allan Poe, Annabel Lee, the characters in Midsummer Night's Dream, the Lord's Prayer, and the 23rd Psalm," Colvin recalls.

#BlackResilience 5/9

Although she endured physical abuse and sexual harassment by police who violently dragged her off of the bus, Claudette remained defiant.

‚ÄúI paid my fare; it‚Äôs my constitutional right," was her response to police questioning.

4/9

On March 2, 1955, 15-year old Claudette boarded a full Montgomery bus across the street from Martin Luther King Jr.'s church.

When the driver ordered her and the Black pregnant woman seated next to her to stand so that a white woman could take their row, Claudette refused.

3/9 https://t.co/XBogmZU8DC

A straight-A student, Claudette took her studies seriously.

She felt deeply connected to the lessons her Black teachers imparted about trailblazing feminist abolitionists like Sojourner Truth and Harriet Tubman (who coincidentally happened to be #nurses).

2/9 https://t.co/vyMaWrGgJd

Nine months before Rosa Parks' historic defiance of segregation, Claudette Colvin ‚Äî a young, smart, working-class, dark-skinned, Black woman ‚Äî refused to stand for white supremacy on a Montgomery bus.

NNU honors this courageous #HealthCareWorker.

A #BlackHistoryMonth thread 1/9 https://t.co/Rn4SVN27cW

Upon returning home, Salaria raised funds for the ongoing fight in Spain saying:
 
"Negro men have given up their lives there... Surely Negro people will willingly give of their means to relieve the suffering of a people attacked by the enemy of all racial minorities: fascism." https://t.co/WdJtJhzpKo

As a member of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Salaria helped transform an old palace into a hospital.
 
There, she treated soldiers from around the world who had joined forces to "make Spain the tomb of fascism."
 
#PatientsFirst üè∞-->üè•

(9/10) https://t.co/dTXPSxeieM

When fascists advanced troops from Ethiopia into Spain, Salaria decided to take her #solidarity a step further.
 
On March 27, 1937 she sailed from New York to Spain to bring #NursePower to the effort to defeat fascism.
 
She was the first Black female RN to do so.

üóΩ‚õµüá™üá∏(8/10)

When Italian fascists invaded Ethiopia, Salaria and her crew were ready.üá™üáπ‚úäüèæ
 
They gathered the first TWO TONS of medical supplies sent from the U.S. ‚û°Ô∏è Ethiopia.
 
Then, they organized resources to set up a 75-bed field hospital for Ethiopians fighting fascism.üî•

(7/10)

Needless to say, Salaria knew some badass nurses.
 
Together, they attended educational events and thought deeply about the connections between local and international events.üåçüß†
 
The rise of fascism in Europe seemed all too familiar to the racism they faced at home.

(6/10)

Did she let that stop her?
 
Nope.
 
Salaria kept organizing. United, health care workers formed a picket line around the hospital and shutüëèüèæ downüëèüèæ the maternity ward while a public investigation of what locals had started calling "Death Hospital" proceeded.
üôÖüèæüíÄüè•

(5/10)

Salaria brought her strong ‚ú®spirit of resistance‚ú® to Harlem Hospital Training School where she attended #NursingSchool.üë©üèæ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è
 
United with her fellow Black nurses, Salaria organized and held collective actions which successfully desegregated the school's dining room. ‚úäüèæ

(3/10)

Despite poverty, the loss of her dad, and separation from her mom, young Salaria excelled in school and sports.üìö‚öΩ
